That is something for which you can be courageously thankful. That is something in which you can discover part of the antidote to the abyss and the darkness.

Be grateful in spite of your suffering. (4/4)

author: jordanbpeterson
content: One that can manifest itself, truly, in the world, in the relationships we have that are grounded in trust and love. (3/4)

author: jordanbpeterson
content: Despite the fact that the world is a very dark place, and that each of us has our black elements of soul, we see in each other a unique blend of actuality and possibility that is a kind of miracle. (2/4)

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
Be grateful in spite of your suffering. 

You might love people despite their limitations, but you also love them because of their limitations.

That is something very much worth understanding. Doing so may help you see how gratitude remains possible. (1/4)

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
It seems to be that you get more courageous, which is way better than being less frightened because there are lots of things to be frightened about.

So if you're courageous, that really does the trick. (5/5)

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
And then, you can deconstruct it into smaller problems and then figure out how to approach those smaller problems. 

It doesn't seem to me that you get less frightened. (4/5)

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
And then, if you don't speak of it, it's way bigger than it should be. As soon as you start talking about it, you've cut it down to size.

You're not as afraid of as many things as you think. And you're braver than you know and more capable. (2/5)

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
If someone's anxious about something, and it's getting in their way, you take what they're anxious about, and you define it.

Because that already delimits it. One of the problems with being anxious about something is you won't speak of it. It's like Voldemort. (1/5)

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
Always look at the single person, one after the other, focus on them, and talk to them as you would an individual. Make sure they're following along.

Listen carefully. If your audience is dead silent, you know you're on the right track. (3/3)

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
Use your personal experience because that's something you're already a master of. You can use other material but it must tie to the real world through your own experience, otherwise it's not real.

Speak directly to the audience, to the individual in the audience. (2/3)

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
A guide to public speaking.

1. You must have incredible knowledge of the topic.
2. You must have a point to speak of.
3. You have multiple stories on hand to illustrate your point.
4. Organise your talk around said point.

Talk about what you know. (1/3)

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
42. Be grateful in spite of your suffering.

There‚Äôs some real utility in gratitude. Gratitude is the process of consciously and courageously attempting thankfulness in the face of the catastrophe of life.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
41. Remember that what you do not yet know is more important than what you already know.

It is much better to make friends with what you do not know than with what you do know, as there is an infinite supply of the former but a finite stock of the latter.

author: jordanbpeterson
content: 40. Write a letter to the government if you see something that needs fixing‚Äìand propose a solution.

author: jordanbpeterson
content: ...If you do it a third time, then I'll say, "Hey, I just noticed this. Not only did it happen, but it happened here. And it happened here. So there's something going on here. I'm not ignoring it."

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
39. Don‚Äôt let bullies get away with it.

I usually use a rule of three:

If we interact and you do something that I find disruptive, I'll note it.

If you do it again, I think, "That probably wasn't merely a situation." I'll leave it be because that's still not enough evidence.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
38. Do not bother children when they are skateboarding.

They jump in the air, grab their skateboard, balance on the rail, and slide for 20 feet.

Children are practicing being courageous. They're practicing mastering something in the face of danger.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
37. Pet a cat when you encounter one on the street.

‚Äã‚ÄãWhen things are not good and hard, you get these little moments where a little bit of possibility still shines through.

You‚Äôve got to take those moments when you get them.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
36. Read something written by someone great.

Carl Jung had an idea that part of personality development is to understand your shadow, the parts of you that you don't want to admit to. You can learn about your shadow by reading history.

A book isn't paper; it's a portal.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
35. Notice that opportunity lurks where responsibility has been abdicated.

You positively need to be occupied with something weighty, deep, profound, and difficult.

What would your life be like if you made use of all the potential that you were offered?

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
34. Do not hide unwanted things in the fog.

There will be times in your life when it will take everything you have to face what is in front of you, instead of hiding away from a truth so terrible that the only thing worse is the falsehood you long to replace it with.

author: jordanbpeterson
content: 33. Do not transform your wife into a maid.

author: jordanbpeterson
content: 32. Do not let your children do anything that makes you dislike them.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
31. Don‚Äôt avoid something frightening if it stands in your way‚Äìand don‚Äôt do unnecessarily dangerous things.

The gradual exposure to what you‚Äôre afraid of is curative. Confront the world forthrightly and expose yourself courageously to things you‚Äôre afraid of. Life will improve.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
30. Stand up straight with your shoulders back.

To stand up straight with your shoulders back is to accept the terrible responsibility of life with eyes wide open. It means deciding to voluntarily transform the chaos of potential into the realities of habitable order.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
...Then you talk about it, name it, and it goes from this blurry thing into a little monster. It's this precision that enables you to specify it.

Now you can do something about it (it's little, at least) if you can admit to it.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
29. Be precise in your speech.

Let's say that you're having a rough patch in your relationship and you don't know why. The issue is unnameable. Is it real? Well, yes, it's manifesting itself in a physiological discomfort.

author: jordanbpeterson
content: 28. Dress like the person you want to be.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
27. Set your house in perfect order before you criticize the world.

The world is harsh. Should you criticize it? Not until you put yourself together. You have to bring everything you can to bear on your problems before you have any right to stand in judgment about Being itself.

author: jordanbpeterson
content: 26. Nothing well done is insignificant.

author: jordanbpeterson
content: 25. And be very careful about rescuing someone who does.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
24. Do not try to rescue someone who does not want to be rescued.

It's a very dangerous activity, and it can easily be counterproductive. The probability that they're going to take you down, compared to you elevating them, is very, very high.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
23. Make friends with people who want the best for you.

You have an ethical responsibility to surround yourself with people who have the courage and faith, and wisdom to wish you well when you've done something good. And to stop you when you're doing something destructive.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
22. Ask someone to do you a small favor so that he or she can ask you to do one in the future.

You don't obsessively keep track of who owes what, when, and why. That's a sign of a degenerating relationship. You do what you can for them, and they do what they can for you.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
21. Treat yourself as if you were someone that you are responsible for helping.

You have a vital role to play in the unfolding destiny of the world. You should take care of, help, and be good to yourself the same way you take care of, help, and be good to someone you love.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
20. Do not carelessly denigrate social institutions or artistic achievement.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need to get married. We don‚Äôt need a piece of paper.‚Äù That‚Äôs the depth of thought you put into it? You‚Äôre not going to mark the occasion with conscious awareness and social celebration?

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
19. Maintain your connections with people.

There is no evidence that the importance of friendship declines in any manner with age.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
18. If old memories still make you cry, write them down carefully and completely.

If you're obsessed with memories of the past (most of them negative), there's a lot of you stuck in the past. Many people have parts of them that are stuck in some traumatic childhood experience.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
17. Work as hard as you possibly can on at least one thing and see what happens.

You will change. You will start to become one thing, instead of the clamoring multitude you once were. It is far better to become something than to remain anything but become nothing.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
16. Compare yourself to who you were yesterday, not to who someone else is today.

The people you compare yourself to you don't know very well. You see a shiny outside but not the reality of their life. Be less concerned with other people's actions. You have plenty to do yourself

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
15. Try to make one room in your house as beautiful as possible.

The world presents itself as a series of puzzles. Some of which you‚Äôre capable of solving and some of which you‚Äôre not.

If you want to change the world, you start with yourself and work outward.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
14. Do not allow yourself to become arrogant or resentful.

If you‚Äôre resentful, you‚Äôre likely not standing up for yourself sufficiently, or someone is legitimately treading on your territory. You need to do something about that. Or live with the consequences.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
13. Imagine who you could be, and then aim single-mindedly at that.

Aim at something profound, noble and lofty. Pick the best target you can conceptualize. Stumble toward it. Notice your errors and misconceptions along the way, and correct them. Confront what stands in your way.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
12. Make at least one thing better every single place you go.

I‚Äôm on the side of the person that wants to do something positive with their life. Start by maximizing the quality of your life. Figure out how to do that in a way that‚Äôs of benefit to your relatives and community.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
11. Be careful who you share bad news with.

You can tell a true friend bad news, and they‚Äôll listen. They won‚Äôt derail the whole conversation about how something worse happened to them once.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
10. Be careful who you share good news with.

You want to share good news with people who will be genuinely happy for you. That‚Äôs one way you can identify those people who are on your side.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
9. Plan and work diligently to maintain the romance in your relationship.

Allow yourself to become aware of what you want and need, and have the decency to let your partner in on the secret. Do not expect the beauty of love to maintain itself without all-out effort on your part.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
8. Listen to them hard enough so that they will share it with you.

The sympathetic responses during a genuine conversation indicate that the teller is valued and that the story being told is important, serious, deserving of consideration, and understandable.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
7. Assume that the person you are listening to might know something you need to know.

You want to enter into a conversation so that you come out wiser than you went in.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
6. Pay attention.

What do you do if your life isn‚Äôt in order? Pay attention. Paying attention is like watching for something you don‚Äôt know. It‚Äôs an unbelievably powerful force.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
5. If you have to choose, be the one who does things instead of the one who is seen to do things.

If you fulfill your obligations every day, you don't need to worry about the future.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
3. Act so that you can tell the truth about how you act.

Stop doing things that you know are wrong, that you could stop doing. It might be a little thing. That‚Äôs fine. Stop doing it, and see what happens. You strengthen yourself.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
2. Do not do things that you hate.

Watch yourself. If you see that you‚Äôre doing things that make you hate yourself, consider the cost of continuing.

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
1. Tell the truth‚Ä¶ or, at least, don‚Äôt lie.

Truth reduces the terrible complexity of a man to the simplicity of his word. Truth is the ultimate, inexhaustible natural resource. It‚Äôs the light in the darkness.

author: jordanbpeterson
content: I don't "miss" this. I don't buy it. Any of it. I believe it's technically wrong, in that institutions built on power (compulsion) are intrinsically unstable. I believe it's demoralizing and morally hazardous simultaneously. And I believe it's motivated by resentment.

author: jordanbpeterson
content: The same line of thought runs through Jung's work (and M Eliade, E Neumann, J Campbell). Those thinkers concluded that the hero myth is the foundational narrative.

author: jordanbpeterson
content: There is an element of postmodern thought I believe to be true although I think the New England pragmatists following CS Pierce formulated it better: that what fundamentally motivates is what is believed to be true. That's a definition of truth.

content:
Similarly, you cannot maintain trust in your partner if he or she lies, or betrays you in action or in silence.
 
So, the vow that makes a marriage capable of preserving its romantic component is first and foremost the decision not to lie to your partner. (3/3)

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
The first of those requirements is truth. 

You cannot maintain trust in yourself if you lie. You cannot maintain trust in yourself, likewise, if you act in a manner that would require a lie if it was discovered. (2/3)

author: jordanbpeterson
content:
Romance requires trust‚Äîand the deeper the trust, the deeper the possibility for romance.

But trust has its requirements, as well.

Apart from the courage required of the individuals wise enough to distrust, but brave enough to risk putting their faith in a partner. (1/3)

author: jordanbpeterson
content: You could come right out and say "even given all that it was time for a (insert race here) x (insert sex here) candidate" but then don't hand-wave injudiciously about excellence uber alles and expect kudos for your performance.

author: jordanbpeterson
content: Finally, you might say "the pool selected a priori was still large enough to ensure sufficient excellence." This just means you don't understand the Pareto principle or the consequences of the power laws governing the manifestation of the highest levels of competence.

author: jordanbpeterson
content: Furthermore, after doing all that, you then stated that your choice was in fact guided by the desire to use the appropriate indicators of competence, whose existence you obviously recognized to begin with (or else you couldn't have listed them).

author: jordanbpeterson
content: It follows, therefore, that you are either ignorant of the consequences of what you are doing, or lying to yourself and/or the people you serve. Or some combination of all three.

author: jordanbpeterson
content: No, you didn't. You announced publicly that you would limit the search to a specific race and sex. You eliminated the vast majority of qualified candidates from consideration. And it is thereby virtually certain, technically, that you failed to pick the strongest candidate.
